day = date of observation for earth crossing (decimal days)
Be = sub-earth latitude on ring plane (= 0 at RPX)
delta2 = Saturn-earth distance (au)
owlt = one way light time, Saturn-earth (days)

day = date of observation for sun crossing
Bs = sub-solar latitude on ring plane (= 0 at solar RPX)
delta1 = Sun-Saturn distance
twlt = two-way light time, sun-Saturn-earth (days)
phase = sun-Saturn-earth phase angle (deg).

The two 'day' columns are because of the differing treatment
of light time in the two cases. The two sets of entries could
be re-interpolated to a common time scale. Note that they differ
by exactly twlt.
------------------------------------------------------------------------
 Rpx2000.out: 1996 Feb            
   Pole: French etal 1993    

  JD 2450123.5: RA =  40.58613 DEC =  83.53714 (J2000)
    (includes pole offset =    0.00   0.00 arcsec)
